inference:
Possible rectangles have vertices at the grid points (0,0), (0,1), ..., (0,4), (1,0), (1,1), ..., (1,4), ..., (4,4).
The possible dimensions are:
1x1: 16 rectangles
1x2: 12 rectangles
1x3: 8 rectangles
1x4: 4 rectangles
2x1: 12 rectangles
2x2: 9 rectangles
2x3: 6 rectangles
2x4: 3 rectangles
3x1: 8 rectangles
3x2: 6 rectangles
3x3: 4 rectangles
3x4: 2 rectangles
4x1: 4 rectangles
4x2: 3 rectangles
4x3: 2 rectangles
4x4: 1 rectangle
Total number of rectangles is 16+12+8+4+12+9+6+3+8+6+4+2+4+3+2+1=100
Total number of squares is 16+9+4+1 = 30
Fraction of squares = 30/100 = 3/10
Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{3}{10}}$
ground_truth:
If we list out the possible sizes of the rectangles, we have: \begin{align*}
&1\times1, \ 1\times2, \ 1\times3, \ 1\times4, \\
&2\times2, \ 2\times3, \ 2\times4, \\
&3\times3, \ 3\times4,\text{ and} \\
&4\times4.
\end{align*} Thus, there are ten possible sizes, each of which must be represented by one rectangle in set $R.$ Four of these sizes are squares, so the fraction in $R$ that are squares is $\frac{4}{10} = \boxed{\frac{2}{5}}.$

ground_truth:
If we list out the possible sizes of the rectangles, we have: \begin{align*}
&1\times1, \ 1\times2, \ 1\times3, \ 1\times4, \\
&2\times2, \ 2\times3, \ 2\times4, \\
&3\times3, \ 3\times4,\text{ and} \\
&4\times4.
\end{align*} Thus, there are ten possible sizes, each of which must be represented by one rectangle in set $R.$ Four of these sizes are squares, so the fraction in $R$ that are squares is $\frac{4}{10} = \boxed{\frac{2}{5}}.$
